ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: 1. Is your child able to express feelings by changes in facial expression? (for example: smiling in response to something that makes him or her happy or frowning in response to something that makes him or her sad)
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 2. Is it typical for your child to be "on the same wavelength" with you?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 3. Is your child able to pretend (engage in make-believe play)?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 4. Does your child have a sense of humor?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 5. Does your child try to involve others in play?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 6. Does your child respond positively to adults who are trying to hold his/her attention?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 7. Does your child look at you (making eye contact) when you are playing together?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 8. When you approach your child to play with him or her, does he/she seem happy to include you or glad that you are involved?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 9. Does your child seem interested in whether you are paying attention to what he or she is doing?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 10. Is your child able to let you know what he or she DOESN'T want?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 11. Is your child able to let you know what he or she DOES want?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 12. Does your child cooperate with an adult's request for help (e.g., clean-up, picking up toys)?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A

ElementDescription: 13. Does your child understand simple verbal requests?
Notes: 0=Not at all; 1=Some what but less than child in video; 2=About the same as child in video; 3=More than child in video; 9=N/A
